par.text: Iridium is a silvery-white, very hard and dense metal. Chemically inert, it is regarded among metals as the most resistant to corrosion. It is not even dissolved by aqua regia (a mixture of 3 parts of concentrated hydrochloric acid and 1 part of concentrated nitric acid by volume), and so is classified as a noble metal. When solidified from the liquid state, iridium has a crystalline structure, imparting considerable ductility, and can be drawn into wires or rolled into sheets. It was discovered by an English chemist, Smithson Tennant, in 1803. Its name is derived from the Latin
- rainbow, because of its multicoloured compounds.
